text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was with God in the beginning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through him all things were made; without him nothing was made that has been made.
speaker: Narrator

text: In him was life, and that life was the light of all mankind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man sent from God whose name was John.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came as a witness to testify concerning that light, so that through him all might believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He himself was not the light; he came only as a witness to the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: The true light that gives light to everyone was coming into the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was in the world, and though the world was made through him, the world did not recognise him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to that which was his own, but his own did not receive him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet to all who did receive him, to those who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God –
speaker: Narrator

text: children born not of natural descent, nor of human decision or a husband’s will, but born of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us. We have seen his glory, the glory of the one and only Son, who came from the Father, full of grace and truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: (John testified concerning him. He cried out, saying, ‘This is the one I spoke about when I said, “He who comes after me has surpassed me because he was before me.”’)
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of his fullness we have all received grace in place of grace already given.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law was given through Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one has ever seen God, but the one and only Son, who is himself God and is in the closest relationship with the Father, has made him known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this was John’s testimony when the Jewish leaders in Jerusalem sent priests and Levites to ask him who he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not fail to confess, but confessed freely, ‘I am not the Messiah.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
They asked him, ‘Then who are you? Are you Elijah?’
He said, ‘I am not.’
‘Are you the Prophet?’
He answered, ‘No.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally they said, ‘Who are you? Give us an answer to take back to those who sent us. What do you say about yourself?’
speaker: Narrator

text: John replied in the words of Isaiah the prophet, ‘I am the voice of one calling in the wilderness, “Make straight the way for the Lord.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Pharisees who had been sent
speaker: Narrator

text: questioned him, ‘Why then do you baptise if you are not the Messiah, nor Elijah, nor the Prophet?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I baptise with water,’ John replied, ‘but among you stands one you do not know.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one who comes after me, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This all happened at Bethany on the other side of the Jordan, where John was baptising.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day John saw Jesus coming towards him and said, ‘Look, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the one I meant when I said, “A man who comes after me has surpassed me because he was before me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself did not know him, but the reason I came baptising with water was that he might be revealed to Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then John gave this testimony: ‘I saw the Spirit come down from heaven as a dove and remain on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I myself did not know him, but the one who sent me to baptise with water told me, “The man on whom you see the Spirit come down and remain is the one who will baptise with the Holy Spirit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen and I testify that this is God’s Chosen One.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day John was there again with two of his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw Jesus passing by, he said, ‘Look, the Lamb of God!’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the two disciples heard him say this, they followed Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turning round, Jesus saw them following and asked, ‘What do you want?’
They said, ‘Rabbi’ (which means ‘Teacher’), ‘where are you staying?’
speaker: Jesus

text:
‘Come,’ he replied, ‘and you will see.’
So they went and saw where he was staying, and they spent that day with him. It was about four in the afternoon.
speaker: Jesus

text: Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother, was one of the two who heard what John had said and who had followed Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first thing Andrew did was to find his brother Simon and tell him, ‘We have found the Messiah’ (that is, the Christ).
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he brought him to Jesus.
Jesus looked at him and said, ‘You are Simon son of John. You will be called Cephas’ (which, when translated, is Peter).
speaker: Jesus

text: The next day Jesus decided to leave for Galilee. Finding Philip, he said to him, ‘Follow me.’
speaker: Jesus

text: Philip, like Andrew and Peter, was from the town of Bethsaida.
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip found Nathanael and told him, ‘We have found the one Moses wrote about in the Law, and about whom the prophets also wrote – Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Nazareth! Can anything good come from there?’ Nathanael asked.
‘Come and see,’ said Philip.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw Nathanael approaching, he said of him, ‘Here truly is an Israelite in whom there is no deceit.’
speaker: Jesus

text:
‘How do you know me?’ Nathanael asked.
Jesus answered, ‘I saw you while you were still under the fig-tree before Philip called you.’
speaker: Jesus

text: Then Nathanael declared, ‘Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the king of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘You believe because I told you I saw you under the fig-tree. You will see greater things than that.’
speaker: Jesus

text: He then added, ‘Very truly I tell you, you will see “heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending on” the Son of Man.’
speaker: Jesus

text: On the third day a wedding took place at Cana in Galilee. Jesus’ mother was there,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jesus and his disciples had also been invited to the wedding.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wine was gone, Jesus’ mother said to him, ‘They have no more wine.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woman, why do you involve me?’ Jesus replied. ‘My hour has not yet come.’
speaker: Jesus

text: His mother said to the servants, ‘Do whatever he tells you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nearby stood six stone water jars, the kind used by the Jews for ceremonial washing, each holding from eighty to a hundred and twenty litres.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to the servants, ‘Fill the jars with water’; so they filled them to the brim.
speaker: Jesus

text:
Then he told them, ‘Now draw some out and take it to the master of the banquet.’
They did so,
speaker: Jesus

text: and the master of the banquet tasted the water that had been turned into wine. He did not realise where it had come from, though the servants who had drawn the water knew. Then he called the bridegroom aside
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, ‘Everyone brings out the choice wine first and then the cheaper wine after the guests have had too much to drink; but you have saved the best till now.’
speaker: Jesus

text: What Jesus did here in Cana of Galilee was the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory; and his disciples believed in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this he went down to Capernaum with his mother and brothers and his disciples. There they stayed for a few days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was almost time for the Jewish Passover, Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the temple courts he found people selling cattle, sheep and doves, and others sitting at tables exchanging money.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he made a whip out of cords, and drove all from the temple courts, both sheep and cattle; he scattered the coins of the money-changers and overturned their tables.
speaker: Narrator

text: To those who sold doves he said, ‘Get these out of here! Stop turning my Father’s house into a market!’
speaker: Jesus

text: His disciples remembered that it is written: ‘Zeal for your house will consume me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews then responded to him, ‘What sign can you show us to prove your authority to do all this?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, ‘Destroy this temple, and I will raise it again in three days.’
speaker: Jesus

text: They replied, ‘It has taken forty-six years to build this temple, and you are going to raise it in three days?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the temple he had spoken of was his body.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he was raised from the dead, his disciples recalled what he had said. Then they believed the Scripture and the words that Jesus had spoken.
speaker: Jesus

text: Now while he was in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, many people saw the signs he was performing and believed in his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus would not entrust himself to them, for he knew all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not need any testimony about mankind, for he knew what was in each person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a Pharisee, a man named Nicodemus who was a member of the Jewish ruling council.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to Jesus at night and said, ‘Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher who has come from God. For no one could perform the signs you are doing if God were not with him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘Very truly I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless they are born again.’
speaker: Jesus

text: ‘How can someone be born when they are old?’ Nicodemus asked. ‘Surely they cannot enter a second time into their mother’s womb to be born!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Very truly I tell you, no one can enter the kingdom of God unless they are born of water and the Spirit.
speaker: Jesus

text: Flesh gives birth to flesh, but the Spirit gives birth to spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should not be surprised at my saying, “You must be born again.”
speaker: Jesus

text: The wind blows wherever it pleases. You hear its sound, but you cannot tell where it comes from or where it is going. So it is with everyone born of the Spirit.’
speaker: Jesus

text: ‘How can this be?’ Nicodemus asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You are Israel’s teacher,’ said Jesus, ‘and do you not understand these things?
speaker: Jesus

text: Very truly I tell you, we speak of what we know, and we testify to what we have seen, but still you people do not accept our testimony.
speaker: Jesus

text: I have spoken to you of earthly things and you do not believe; how then will you believe if I speak of heavenly things?
speaker: Jesus

text: No one has ever gone into heaven except the one who came from heaven – the Son of Man.
speaker: Jesus

text: Just as Moses lifted up the snake in the wilderness, so the Son of Man must be lifted up,
speaker: Jesus

text: that everyone who believes may have eternal life in him.’
speaker: Jesus

text: For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.
speaker: Jesus

text: For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but to save the world through him.
speaker: Jesus

text: Whoever believes in him is not condemned, but whoever does not believe stands condemned already because they have not believed in the name of God’s one and only Son.
speaker: Jesus

text: This is the verdict: light has come into the world, but people loved darkness instead of light because their deeds were evil.
speaker: Jesus

text: Everyone who does evil hates the light, and will not come into the light for fear that their deeds will be exposed.
speaker: Jesus

text: But whoever lives by the truth comes into the light, so that it may be seen plainly that what they have done has been done in the sight of God.
speaker: Jesus

text: After this, Jesus and his disciples went out into the Judean countryside, where he spent some time with them, and baptised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now John also was baptising at Aenon near Salim, because there was plenty of water, and people were coming and being baptised.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This was before John was put in prison.)
speaker: Narrator

text: An argument developed between some of John’s disciples and a certain Jew over the matter of ceremonial washing.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to John and said to him, ‘Rabbi, that man who was with you on the other side of the Jordan – the one you testified about – look, he is baptising, and everyone is going to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: To this John replied, ‘A person can receive only what is given them from heaven.
speaker: Jesus

text: You yourselves can testify that I said, “I am not the Messiah but am sent ahead of him.”
speaker: Jesus

text: The bride belongs to the bridegroom. The friend who attends the bridegroom waits and listens for him, and is full of joy when he hears the bridegroom’s voice. That joy is mine, and it is now complete.
speaker: Jesus

text: He must become greater; I must become less.’
speaker: Jesus

text: The one who comes from above is above all; the one who is from the earth belongs to the earth, and speaks as one from the earth. The one who comes from heaven is above all.
speaker: Jesus

text: He testifies to what he has seen and heard, but no one accepts his testimony.
speaker: Jesus

text: Whoever has accepted it has certified that God is truthful.
speaker: Jesus

text: For the one whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for God gives the Spirit without limit.
speaker: Jesus

text: The Father loves the Son and has placed everything in his hands.
speaker: Jesus

text: Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life, but whoever rejects the Son will not see life, for God’s wrath remains on them.
speaker: Jesus

text: Now Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard that he was gaining and baptising more disciples than John –
speaker: Narrator

text: although in fact it was not Jesus who baptised, but his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he left Judea and went back once more to Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he had to go through Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he came to a town in Samaria called Sychar, near the plot of ground Jacob had given to his son Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob’s well was there, and Jesus, tired as he was from the journey, sat down by the well. It was about noon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a Samaritan woman came to draw water, Jesus said to her, ‘Will you give me a drink?’
speaker: Narrator

text: (His disciples had gone into the town to buy food.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The Samaritan woman said to him, ‘You are a Jew and I am a Samaritan woman. How can you ask me for a drink?’ (For Jews do not associate with Samaritans.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered her, ‘If you knew the gift of God and who it is that asks you for a drink, you would have asked him and he would have given you living water.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Sir,’ the woman said, ‘you have nothing to draw with and the well is deep. Where can you get this living water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank from it himself, as did also his sons and his livestock?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Everyone who drinks this water will be thirsty again,
speaker: Narrator

text: but whoever drinks the water I give them will never thirst. Indeed, the water I give them will become in them a spring of water welling up to eternal life.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said to him, ‘Sir, give me this water so that I won’t get thirsty and have to keep coming here to draw water.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He told her, ‘Go, call your husband and come back.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I have no husband,’ she replied.
Jesus said to her, ‘You are right when you say you have no husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fact is, you have had five husbands, and the man you now have is not your husband. What you have just said is quite true.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Sir,’ the woman said, ‘I can see that you are a prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestors worshipped on this mountain, but you Jews claim that the place where we must worship is in Jerusalem.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Woman,’ Jesus replied, ‘believe me, a time is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: You Samaritans worship what you do not know; we worship what we do know, for salvation is from the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet a time is coming and has now come when the true worshippers will worship the Father in the Spirit and in truth, for they are the kind of worshippers the Father seeks.
speaker: Narrator

text: God is spirit, and his worshippers must worship in the Spirit and in truth.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said, ‘I know that Messiah’ (called Christ) ‘is coming. When he comes, he will explain everything to us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus declared, ‘I, the one speaking to you – I am he.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then his disciples returned and were surprised to find him talking with a woman. But no one asked, ‘What do you want?’ or ‘Why are you talking with her?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, leaving her water jar, the woman went back to the town and said to the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Come, see a man who told me everything I’ve ever done. Could this be the Messiah?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They came out of the town and made their way towards him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile his disciples urged him, ‘Rabbi, eat something.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to them, ‘I have food to eat that you know nothing about.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his disciples said to each other, ‘Could someone have brought him food?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My food,’ said Jesus, ‘is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you have a saying, “It’s still four months until harvest”? I tell you, open your eyes and look at the fields! They are ripe for harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even now the one who reaps draws a wage and harvests a crop for eternal life, so that the sower and the reaper may be glad together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the saying “One sows and another reaps” is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: I sent you to reap what you have not worked for. Others have done the hard work, and you have reaped the benefits of their labour.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of the Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman’s testimony, ‘He told me everything I’ve ever done.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the Samaritans came to him, they urged him to stay with them, and he stayed two days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because of his words many more became believers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to the woman, ‘We no longer believe just because of what you said; now we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this man really is the Saviour of the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After the two days he left for Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now Jesus himself had pointed out that a prophet has no honour in his own country.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived in Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him. They had seen all that he had done in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, for they also had been there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once more he visited Cana in Galilee, where he had turned the water into wine. And there was a certain royal official whose son lay ill at Capernaum.
speaker: Narrator

text: When this man heard that Jesus had arrived in Galilee from Judea, he went to him and begged him to come and heal his son, who was close to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Unless you people see signs and wonders,’ Jesus told him, ‘you will never believe.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The royal official said, ‘Sir, come down before my child dies.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Go,’ Jesus replied, ‘your son will live.’
The man took Jesus at his word and departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still on the way, his servants met him with the news that his boy was living.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he enquired as to the time when his son got better, they said to him, ‘Yesterday, at one in the afternoon, the fever left him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the father realised that this was the exact time at which Jesus had said to him, ‘Your son will live.’ So he and his whole household believed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the second sign Jesus performed after coming from Judea to Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Jesus went up to Jerusalem for one of the Jewish festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there is in Jerusalem near the Sheep Gate a pool, which in Aramaic is called Bethesda and which is surrounded by five covered colonnades.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here a great number of disabled people used to lie – the blind, the lame, the paralysed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One who was there had been an invalid for thirty-eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw him lying there and learned that he had been in this condition for a long time, he asked him, ‘Do you want to get well?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Sir,’ the invalid replied, ‘I have no one to help me into the pool when the water is stirred. While I am trying to get in, someone else goes down ahead of me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to him, ‘Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
At once the man was cured; he picked up his mat and walked.
The day on which this took place was a Sabbath,
speaker: Narrator

text: and so the Jewish leaders said to the man who had been healed, ‘It is the Sabbath; the law forbids you to carry your mat.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, ‘The man who made me well said to me, “Pick up your mat and walk.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they asked him, ‘Who is this fellow who told you to pick it up and walk?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who was healed had no idea who it was, for Jesus had slipped away into the crowd that was there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later Jesus found him at the temple and said to him, ‘See, you are well again. Stop sinning or something worse may happen to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The man went away and told the Jewish leaders that it was Jesus who had made him well.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, because Jesus was doing these things on the Sabbath, the Jewish leaders began to persecute him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his defence Jesus said to them, ‘My Father is always at his work to this very day, and I too am working.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason they tried all the more to kill him; not only was he breaking the Sabbath, but he was even calling God his own Father, making himself equal with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus gave them this answer: ‘Very truly I tell you, the Son can do nothing by himself; he can do only what he sees his Father doing, because whatever the Father does the Son also does.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Father loves the Son and shows him all he does. Yes, and he will show him even greater works than these, so that you will be amazed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the Father raises the dead and gives them life, even so the Son gives life to whom he is pleased to give it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Father judges no one, but has entrusted all judgment to the Son,
speaker: Narrator

text: that all may honour the Son just as they honour the Father. Whoever does not honour the Son does not honour the Father, who sent him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Very truly I tell you, whoever hears my word and believes him who sent me has eternal life and will not be judged but has crossed over from death to life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, a time is coming and has now come when the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God and those who hear will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as the Father has life in himself, so he has granted the Son also to have life in himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he has given him authority to judge because he is the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Do not be amazed at this, for a time is coming when all who are in their graves will hear his voice
speaker: Narrator

text: and come out – those who have done what is good will rise to live, and those who have done what is evil will rise to be condemned.
speaker: Narrator

text: By myself I can do nothing; I judge only as I hear, and my judgment is just, for I seek not to please myself but him who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If I testify about myself, my testimony is not true.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is another who testifies in my favour, and I know that his testimony about me is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have sent to John and he has testified to the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not that I accept human testimony; but I mention it that you may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: John was a lamp that burned and gave light, and you chose for a time to enjoy his light.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I have testimony weightier than that of John. For the works that the Father has given me to finish – the very works that I am doing – testify that the Father has sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Father who sent me has himself testified concerning me. You have never heard his voice nor seen his form,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor does his word dwell in you, for you do not believe the one he sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You study the Scriptures diligently because you think that in them you have eternal life. These are the very Scriptures that testify about me,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet you refuse to come to me to have life.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I do not accept glory from human beings,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I know you. I know that you do not have the love of God in your hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have come in my Father’s name, and you do not accept me; but if someone else comes in his own name, you will accept him.
speaker: Narrator

text: How can you believe since you accept glory from one another but do not seek the glory that comes from the only God?
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But do not think I will accuse you before the Father. Your accuser is Moses, on whom your hopes are set.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you believed Moses, you would believe me, for he wrote about me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But since you do not believe what he wrote, how are you going to believe what I say?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time after this, Jesus crossed to the far shore of the Sea of Galilee (that is, the Sea of Tiberias),
speaker: Narrator

text: and a great crowd of people followed him because they saw the signs he had performed by healing those who were ill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went up on a mountainside and sat down with his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jewish Passover Festival was near.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus looked up and saw a great crowd coming towards him, he said to Philip, ‘Where shall we buy bread for these people to eat?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked this only to test him, for he already had in mind what he was going to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip answered him, ‘It would take more than half a year’s wages to buy enough bread for each one to have a bite!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Another of his disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother, spoke up,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Here is a boy with five small barley loaves and two small fish, but how far will they go among so many?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘Make the people sit down.’ There was plenty of grass in that place, and they sat down (about five thousand men were there).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus then took the loaves, gave thanks, and distributed to those who were seated as much as they wanted. He did the same with the fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had all had enough to eat, he said to his disciples, ‘Gather the pieces that are left over. Let nothing be wasted.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gathered them and filled twelve baskets with the pieces of the five barley loaves left over by those who had eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the people saw the sign Jesus performed, they began to say, ‘Surely this is the Prophet who is to come into the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, knowing that they intended to come and make him king by force, withdrew again to a mountain by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When evening came, his disciples went down to the lake,
speaker: Narrator

text: where they got into a boat and set off across the lake for Capernaum. By now it was dark, and Jesus had not yet joined them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A strong wind was blowing and the waters grew rough.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had rowed about three or four miles, they saw Jesus approaching the boat, walking on the water; and they were frightened.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to them, ‘It is I; don’t be afraid.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they were willing to take him into the boat, and immediately the boat reached the shore where they were heading.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the crowd that had stayed on the opposite shore of the lake realised that only one boat had been there, and that Jesus had not entered it with his disciples, but that they had gone away alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some boats from Tiberias landed near the place where the people had eaten the bread after the Lord had given thanks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once the crowd realised that neither Jesus nor his disciples were there, they got into the boats and went to Capernaum in search of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they found him on the other side of the lake, they asked him, ‘Rabbi, when did you get here?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Very truly I tell you, you are looking for me, not because you saw the signs I performed but because you ate the loaves and had your fill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not work for food that spoils, but for food that endures to eternal life, which the Son of Man will give you. For on him God the Father has placed his seal of approval.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they asked him, ‘What must we do to do the works God requires?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they asked him, ‘What sign then will you give that we may see it and believe you? What will you do?
speaker: Narrator

text: Our ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness; as it is written: “He gave them bread from heaven to eat.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘Very truly I tell you, it is not Moses who has given you the bread from heaven, but it is my Father who gives you the true bread from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the bread of God is the bread that comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Sir,’ they said, ‘always give us this bread.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus declared, ‘I am the bread of life. Whoever comes to me will never go hungry, and whoever believes in me will never be thirsty.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as I told you, you have seen me and still you do not believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: All those the Father gives me will come to me, and whoever comes to me I will never drive away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is the will of him who sent me, that I shall lose none of all those he has given me, but raise them up at the last day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my Father’s will is that everyone who looks to the Son and believes in him shall have eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this the Jews there began to grumble about him because he said, ‘I am the bread that came down from heaven.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, ‘Is this not Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? How can he now say, “I came down from heaven”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Stop grumbling among yourselves,’ Jesus answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘No one can come to me unless the Father who sent me draws them, and I will raise them up at the last day.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is written in the Prophets: “They will all be taught by God.” Everyone who has heard the Father and learned from him comes to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one has seen the Father except the one who is from God; only he has seen the Father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, the one who believes has eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the bread of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness, yet they died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But here is the bread that comes down from heaven, which anyone may eat and not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the living bread that came down from heaven. Whoever eats this bread will live for ever. This bread is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Jews began to argue sharply among themselves, ‘How can this man give us his flesh to eat?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘Very truly I tell you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you have no life in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my flesh is real food and my blood is real drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the living Father sent me and I live because of the Father, so the one who feeds on me will live because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the bread that came down from heaven. Your ancestors ate manna and died, but whoever feeds on this bread will live for ever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said this while teaching in the synagogue in Capernaum.
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing it, many of his disciples said, ‘This is a hard teaching. Who can accept it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Aware that his disciples were grumbling about this, Jesus said to them, ‘Does this offend you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what if you see the Son of Man ascend to where he was before!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit gives life; the flesh counts for nothing. The words I have spoken to you – they are full of the Spirit and life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet there are some of you who do not believe.’ For Jesus had known from the beginning which of them did not believe and who would betray him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on to say, ‘This is why I told you that no one can come to me unless the Father has enabled them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: From this time many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You do not want to leave too, do you?’ Jesus asked the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simon Peter answered him, ‘Lord, to whom shall we go? You have the words of eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have come to believe and to know that you are the Holy One of God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus replied, ‘Have I not chosen you, the Twelve? Yet one of you is a devil!’
speaker: Narrator

text: (He meant Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, who, though one of the Twelve, was later to betray him.)
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jesus went around in Galilee. He did not want to go about in Judea because the Jewish leaders there were looking for a way to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jewish Festival of Tabernacles was near,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus’ brothers said to him, ‘Leave Galilee and go to Judea, so that your disciples there may see the works you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one who wants to become a public figure acts in secret. Since you are doing these things, show yourself to the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For even his own brothers did not believe in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus told them, ‘My time is not yet here; for you any time will do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify that its works are evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: You go to the festival. I am not going up to this festival, because my time has not yet fully come.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said this, he stayed in Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, after his brothers had left for the festival, he went also, not publicly, but in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now at the festival the Jewish leaders were watching for Jesus and asking, ‘Where is he?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the crowds there was widespread whispering about him. Some said, ‘He is a good man.’
Others replied, ‘No, he deceives the people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But no one would say anything publicly about him for fear of the leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not until halfway through the festival did Jesus go up to the temple courts and begin to teach.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews there were amazed and asked, ‘How did this man get such learning without having been taught?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘My teaching is not my own. It comes from the one who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who chooses to do the will of God will find out whether my teaching comes from God or whether I speak on my own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever speaks on their own does so to gain personal glory, but he who seeks the glory of the one who sent him is a man of truth; there is nothing false about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has not Moses given you the law? Yet not one of you keeps the law. Why are you trying to kill me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You are demon-possessed,’ the crowd answered. ‘Who is trying to kill you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘I did one miracle, and you are all amazed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, because Moses gave you circumcision (though actually it did not come from Moses, but from the patriarchs), you circumcise a boy on the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if a boy can be circumcised on the Sabbath so that the law of Moses may not be broken, why are you angry with me for healing a man’s whole body on the Sabbath?
speaker: Narrator

text: Stop judging by mere appearances, but instead judge correctly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: At that point some of the people of Jerusalem began to ask, ‘Isn’t this the man they are trying to kill?
speaker: Narrator

text: Here he is, speaking publicly, and they are not saying a word to him. Have the authorities really concluded that he is the Messiah?
speaker: Narrator

text: But we know where this man is from; when the Messiah comes, no one will know where he is from.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus, still teaching in the temple courts, cried out, ‘Yes, you know me, and you know where I am from. I am not here on my own authority, but he who sent me is true. You do not know him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I know him because I am from him and he sent me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this they tried to seize him, but no one laid a hand on him, because his hour had not yet come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, many in the crowd believed in him. They said, ‘When the Messiah comes, will he perform more signs than this man?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees heard the crowd whispering such things about him. Then the chief priests and the Pharisees sent temple guards to arrest him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘I am with you for only a short time, and then I am going to the one who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will look for me, but you will not find me; and where I am, you cannot come.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews said to one another, ‘Where does this man intend to go that we cannot find him? Will he go where our people live scattered among the Greeks, and teach the Greeks?
speaker: Narrator

text: What did he mean when he said, “You will look for me, but you will not find me,” and “Where I am, you cannot come”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: On the last and greatest day of the festival, Jesus stood and said in a loud voice, ‘Let anyone who is thirsty come to me and drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever believes in me, as Scripture has said, rivers of living water will flow from within them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: By this he meant the Spirit, whom those who believed in him were later to receive. Up to that time the Spirit had not been given, since Jesus had not yet been glorified.
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing his words, some of the people said, ‘Surely this man is the Prophet.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Others said, ‘He is the Messiah.’
Still others asked, ‘How can the Messiah come from Galilee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Does not Scripture say that the Messiah will come from David’s descendants and from Bethlehem, the town where David lived?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the people were divided because of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some wanted to seize him, but no one laid a hand on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally the temple guards went back to the chief priests and the Pharisees, who asked them, ‘Why didn’t you bring him in?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘No one ever spoke the way this man does,’ the guards replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You mean he has deceived you also?’ the Pharisees retorted.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Have any of the rulers or of the Pharisees believed in him?
speaker: Narrator

text: No! But this mob that knows nothing of the law – there is a curse on them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nicodemus, who had gone to Jesus earlier and who was one of their own number, asked,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Does our law condemn a man without first hearing him to find out what he has been doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, ‘Are you from Galilee, too? Look into it, and you will find that a prophet does not come out of Galilee.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all went home,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.
speaker: Narrator

text: At dawn he appeared again in the temple courts, where all the people gathered round him, and he sat down to teach them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The teachers of the law and the Pharisees brought in a woman caught in adultery. They made her stand before the group
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Jesus, ‘Teacher, this woman was caught in the act of adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the Law Moses commanded us to stone such women. Now what do you say?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were using this question as a trap, in order to have a basis for accusing him.
But Jesus bent down and started to write on the ground with his finger.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they kept on questioning him, he straightened up and said to them, ‘Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he stooped down and wrote on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, those who heard began to go away one at a time, the older ones first, until only Jesus was left, with the woman still standing there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus straightened up and asked her, ‘Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘No one, sir,’ she said.
‘Then neither do I condemn you,’ Jesus declared. ‘Go now and leave your life of sin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus spoke again to the people, he said, ‘I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will never walk in darkness, but will have the light of life.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees challenged him, ‘Here you are, appearing as your own witness; your testimony is not valid.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Even if I testify on my own behalf, my testimony is valid, for I know where I came from and where I am going. But you have no idea where I come from or where I am going.
speaker: Narrator

text: You judge by human standards; I pass judgment on no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I do judge, my decisions are true, because I am not alone. I stand with the Father, who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your own Law it is written that the testimony of two witnesses is true.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am one who testifies for myself; my other witness is the Father, who sent me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they asked him, ‘Where is your father?’
‘You do not know me or my Father,’ Jesus replied. ‘If you knew me, you would know my Father also.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke these words while teaching in the temple courts near the place where the offerings were put. Yet no one seized him, because his hour had not yet come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once more Jesus said to them, ‘I am going away, and you will look for me, and you will die in your sin. Where I go, you cannot come.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This made the Jews ask, ‘Will he kill himself? Is that why he says, “Where I go, you cannot come”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he continued, ‘You are from below; I am from above. You are of this world; I am not of this world.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told you that you would die in your sins; if you do not believe that I am he, you will indeed die in your sins.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Who are you?’ they asked.
‘Just what I have been telling you from the beginning,’ Jesus replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I have much to say in judgment of you. But he who sent me is trustworthy, and what I have heard from him I tell the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not understand that he was telling them about his Father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jesus said, ‘When you have lifted up the Son of Man, then you will know that I am he and that I do nothing on my own but speak just what the Father has taught me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who sent me is with me; he has not left me alone, for I always do what pleases him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Even as he spoke, many believed in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Jews who had believed him, Jesus said, ‘If you hold to my teaching, you are really my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered him, ‘We are Abraham’s descendants and have never been slaves of anyone. How can you say that we shall be set free?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘Very truly I tell you, everyone who sins is a slave to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a slave has no permanent place in the family, but a son belongs to it for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if the Son sets you free, you will be free indeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know you are Abraham’s descendants. Yet you are looking for a way to kill me, because you have no room for my word.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am telling you what I have seen in the Father’s presence, and you are doing what you have heard from your father.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Abraham is our father,’ they answered.
‘If you were Abraham’s children,’ said Jesus, ‘then you would do what Abraham did.
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is, you are looking for a way to kill me, a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God. Abraham did not do such things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are doing the works of your own father.’
‘We are not illegitimate children,’ they protested. ‘The only Father we have is God himself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, ‘If God were your Father, you would love me, for I have come here from God. I have not come on my own; God sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is my language not clear to you? Because you are unable to hear what I say.
speaker: Narrator

text: You belong to your father, the devil, and you want to carry out your father’s desires. He was a murderer from the beginning, not holding to the truth, for there is no truth in him. When he lies, he speaks his native language, for he is a liar and the father of lies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet because I tell the truth, you do not believe me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Can any of you prove me guilty of sin? If I am telling the truth, why don’t you believe me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever belongs to God hears what God says. The reason you do not hear is that you do not belong to God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews answered him, ‘Aren’t we right in saying that you are a Samaritan and demon-possessed?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am not possessed by a demon,’ said Jesus, ‘but I honour my Father and you dishonour me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not seeking glory for myself; but there is one who seeks it, and he is the judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, whoever obeys my word will never see death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this they exclaimed, ‘Now we know that you are demon-possessed! Abraham died and so did the prophets, yet you say that whoever obeys your word will never taste death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you greater than our father Abraham? He died, and so did the prophets. Who do you think you are?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘If I glorify myself, my glory means nothing. My Father, whom you claim as your God, is the one who glorifies me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though you do not know him, I know him. If I said I did not, I would be a liar like you, but I do know him and obey his word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your father Abraham rejoiced at the thought of seeing my day; he saw it and was glad.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You are not yet fifty years old,’ they said to him, ‘and you have seen Abraham!’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Very truly I tell you,’ Jesus answered, ‘before Abraham was born, I am!’
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, they picked up stones to stone him, but Jesus hid himself, slipping away from the temple grounds.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he went along, he saw a man blind from birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples asked him, ‘Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Neither this man nor his parents sinned,’ said Jesus, ‘but this happened so that the works of God might be displayed in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as it is day, we must do the works of him who sent me. Night is coming, when no one can work.
speaker: Narrator

text: While I am in the world, I am the light of the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying this, he spat on the ground, made some mud with the saliva, and put it on the man’s eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Go,’ he told him, ‘wash in the Pool of Siloam’ (this word means ‘Sent’). So the man went and washed, and came home seeing.
speaker: Narrator

text: His neighbours and those who had formerly seen him begging asked, ‘Isn’t this the same man who used to sit and beg?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some claimed that he was.
Others said, ‘No, he only looks like him.’
But he himself insisted, ‘I am the man.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘How then were your eyes opened?’ they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘The man they call Jesus made some mud and put it on my eyes. He told me to go to Siloam and wash. So I went and washed, and then I could see.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Where is this man?’ they asked him.
‘I don’t know,’ he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought to the Pharisees the man who had been blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the day on which Jesus had made the mud and opened the man’s eyes was a Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Pharisees also asked him how he had received his sight. ‘He put mud on my eyes,’ the man replied, ‘and I washed, and now I see.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some of the Pharisees said, ‘This man is not from God, for he does not keep the Sabbath.’
But others asked, ‘How can a sinner perform such signs?’ So they were divided.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they turned again to the blind man, ‘What have you to say about him? It was your eyes he opened.’
The man replied, ‘He is a prophet.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They still did not believe that he had been blind and had received his sight until they sent for the man’s parents.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Is this your son?’ they asked. ‘Is this the one you say was born blind? How is it that now he can see?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘We know he is our son,’ the parents answered, ‘and we know he was born blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: But how he can see now, or who opened his eyes, we don’t know. Ask him. He is of age; he will speak for himself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: His parents said this because they were afraid of the Jewish leaders, who already had decided that anyone who acknowledged that Jesus was the Messiah would be put out of the synagogue.
speaker: Narrator

text: That was why his parents said, ‘He is of age; ask him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: A second time they summoned the man who had been blind. ‘Give glory to God by telling the truth,’ they said. ‘We know this man is a sinner.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘Whether he is a sinner or not, I don’t know. One thing I do know. I was blind but now I see!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they asked him, ‘What did he do to you? How did he open your eyes?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, ‘I have told you already and you did not listen. Why do you want to hear it again? Do you want to become his disciples too?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they hurled insults at him and said, ‘You are this fellow’s disciple! We are disciples of Moses!
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that God spoke to Moses, but as for this fellow, we don’t even know where he comes from.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The man answered, ‘Now that is remarkable! You don’t know where he comes from, yet he opened my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that God does not listen to sinners. He listens to the godly person who does his will.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nobody has ever heard of opening the eyes of a man born blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this man were not from God, he could do nothing.’
speaker: Narrator

text: To this they replied, ‘You were steeped in sin at birth; how dare you lecture us!’ And they threw him out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus heard that they had thrown him out, and when he found him, he said, ‘Do you believe in the Son of Man?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Who is he, sir?’ the man asked. ‘Tell me so that I may believe in him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘You have now seen him; in fact, he is the one speaking with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said, ‘Lord, I believe,’ and he worshipped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘For judgment I have come into this world, so that the blind will see and those who see will become blind.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Pharisees who were with him heard him say this and asked, ‘What? Are we blind too?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘If you were blind, you would not be guilty of sin; but now that you claim you can see, your guilt remains.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Very truly I tell you Pharisees, anyone who does not enter the sheepfold by the gate, but climbs in by some other way, is a thief and a robber.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who enters by the gate is the shepherd of the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeeper opens the gate for him, and the sheep listen to his voice. He calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he has brought out all his own, he goes on ahead of them, and his sheep follow him because they know his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they will never follow a stranger; in fact, they will run away from him because they do not recognise a stranger’s voice.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus used this figure of speech, but the Pharisees did not understand what he was telling them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus said again, ‘Very truly I tell you, I am the gate for the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who have come before me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep have not listened to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the gate; whoever enters through me will be saved. They will come in and go out, and find pasture.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs away. Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man runs away because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am the good shepherd; I know my sheep and my sheep know me –
speaker: Narrator

text: just as the Father knows me and I know the Father – and I lay down my life for the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have other sheep that are not of this sheepfold. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text: The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my life – only to take it up again.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews who heard these words were again divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of them said, ‘He is demon-possessed and raving mad. Why listen to him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But others said, ‘These are not the sayings of a man possessed by a demon. Can a demon open the eyes of the blind?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then came the Festival of Dedication at Jerusalem. It was winter,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jesus was in the temple courts walking in Solomon’s Colonnade.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jews who were there gathered round him, saying, ‘How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘I did tell you, but you do not believe. The works I do in my Father’s name testify about me,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you do not believe because you are not my sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: My sheep listen to my voice; I know them, and they follow me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; no one will snatch them out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: My Father, who has given them to me, is greater than all; no one can snatch them out of my Father’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: I and the Father are one.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Again his Jewish opponents picked up stones to stone him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Jesus said to them, ‘I have shown you many good works from the Father. For which of these do you stone me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘We are not stoning you for any good work,’ they replied, ‘but for blasphemy, because you, a mere man, claim to be God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, ‘Is it not written in your Law, “I have said you are ‘gods’”?
speaker: Narrator

text: If he called them “gods”, to whom the word of God came – and Scripture cannot be set aside –
speaker: Narrator

text: what about the one whom the Father set apart as his very own and sent into the world? Why then do you accuse me of blasphemy because I said, “I am God’s Son”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not believe me unless I do the works of my Father.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I do them, even though you do not believe me, believe the works, that you may know and understand that the Father is in me, and I in the Father.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Again they tried to seize him, but he escaped their grasp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went back across the Jordan to the place where John had been baptising in the early days. There he stayed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and many people came to him. They said, ‘Though John never performed a sign, all that John said about this man was true.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that place many believed in Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man named Lazarus was ill. He was from Bethany, the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This Mary, whose brother Lazarus now lay ill, was the same one who poured perfume on the Lord and wiped his feet with her hair.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sisters sent word to Jesus, ‘Lord, the one you love is ill.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard this, Jesus said, ‘This illness will not end in death. No, it is for God’s glory so that God’s Son may be glorified through it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when he heard that Lazarus was ill, he stayed where he was two more days,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then he said to his disciples, ‘Let us go back to Judea.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But Rabbi,’ they said, ‘a short while ago the Jews there tried to stone you, and yet you are going back?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Are there not twelve hours of daylight? Anyone who walks in the day-time will not stumble, for they see by this world’s light.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is when a person walks at night that they stumble, for they have no light.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said this, he went on to tell them, ‘Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep; but I am going there to wake him up.’
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples replied, ‘Lord, if he sleeps, he will get better.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus had been speaking of his death, but his disciples thought he meant natural sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then he told them plainly, ‘Lazarus is dead,
speaker: Narrator

text: and for your sake I am glad I was not there, so that you may believe. But let us go to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Thomas (also known as Didymus) said to the rest of the disciples, ‘Let us also go, that we may die with him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: On his arrival, Jesus found that Lazarus had already been in the tomb for four days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Bethany was less than two miles from Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: and many Jews had come to Martha and Mary to comfort them in the loss of their brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went out to meet him, but Mary stayed at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Lord,’ Martha said to Jesus, ‘if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I know that even now God will give you whatever you ask.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to her, ‘Your brother will rise again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Martha answered, ‘I know he will rise again in the resurrection at the last day.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to her, ‘I am the resurrection and the life. The one who believes in me will live, even though they die;
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever lives by believing in me will never die. Do you believe this?’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Yes, Lord,’ she replied, ‘I believe that you are the Messiah, the Son of God, who is to come into the world.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After she had said this, she went back and called her sister Mary aside. ‘The Teacher is here,’ she said, ‘and is asking for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mary heard this, she got up quickly and went to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jesus had not yet entered the village, but was still at the place where Martha had met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Jews who had been with Mary in the house, comforting her, noticed how quickly she got up and went out, they followed her, supposing she was going to the tomb to mourn there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mary reached the place where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet and said, ‘Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw her weeping, and the Jews who had come along with her also weeping, he was deeply moved in spirit and troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Where have you laid him?’ he asked.
‘Come and see, Lord,’ they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Jews said, ‘See how he loved him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of them said, ‘Could not he who opened the eyes of the blind man have kept this man from dying?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, once more deeply moved, came to the tomb. It was a cave with a stone laid across the entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Take away the stone,’ he said.
‘But, Lord,’ said Martha, the sister of the dead man, ‘by this time there is a bad odour, for he has been there four days.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said, ‘Did I not tell you that if you believe, you will see the glory of God?’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took away the stone. Then Jesus looked up and said, ‘Father, I thank you that you have heard me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I knew that you always hear me, but I said this for the benefit of the people standing here, that they may believe that you sent me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had said this, Jesus called in a loud voice, ‘Lazarus, come out!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The dead man came out, his hands and feet wrapped with strips of linen, and a cloth round his face.
Jesus said to them, ‘Take off the grave clothes and let him go.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore many of the Jews who had come to visit Mary, and had seen what Jesus did, believed in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the chief priests and the Pharisees called a meeting of the Sanhedrin.
‘What are we accomplishing?’ they asked. ‘Here is this man performing many signs.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we let him go on like this, everyone will believe in him, and then the Romans will come and take away both our temple and our nation.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of them, named Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, spoke up, ‘You know nothing at all!
speaker: Narrator

text: You do not realise that it is better for you that one man die for the people than that the whole nation perish.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not say this on his own, but as high priest that year he prophesied that Jesus would die for the Jewish nation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and not only for that nation but also for the scattered children of God, to bring them together and make them one.
speaker: Narrator

text: So from that day on they plotted to take his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus no longer moved about publicly among the people of Judea. Instead he withdrew to a region near the wilderness, to a village called Ephraim, where he stayed with his disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was almost time for the Jewish Passover, many went up from the country to Jerusalem for their ceremonial cleansing before the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept looking for Jesus, and as they stood in the temple courts they asked one another, ‘What do you think? Isn’t he coming to the festival at all?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that anyone who found out where Jesus was should report it so that they might arrest him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus lived, whom Jesus had raised from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here a dinner was given in Jesus’ honour. Martha served, while Lazarus was among those reclining at the table with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Mary took about half a litre of pure nard, an expensive perfume; she poured it on Jesus’ feet and wiped his feet with her hair. And the house was filled with the fragrance of the perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of his disciples, Judas Iscariot, who was later to betray him, objected,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Why wasn’t this perfume sold and the money given to the poor? It was worth a year’s wages.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not say this because he cared about the poor but because he was a thief; as keeper of the money bag, he used to help himself to what was put into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Leave her alone,’ Jesus replied. ‘It was intended that she should save this perfume for the day of my burial.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will always have the poor among you, but you will not always have me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile a large crowd of Jews found out that Jesus was there and came, not only because of him but also to see Lazarus, whom he had raised from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the chief priests made plans to kill Lazarus as well,
speaker: Narrator

text: for on account of him many of the Jews were going over to Jesus and believing in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the great crowd that had come for the festival heard that Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They took palm branches and went out to meet him, shouting,
‘Hosanna!’
‘Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!’
‘Blessed is the king of Israel!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus found a young donkey and sat upon it, as it is written:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: At first his disciples did not understand all this. Only after Jesus was glorified did they realise that these things had been written about him and that these things had been done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the crowd that was with him when he called Lazarus from the tomb and raised him from the dead continued to spread the word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many people, because they had heard that he had performed this sign, went out to meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Pharisees said to one another, ‘See, this is getting us nowhere. Look how the whole world has gone after him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were some Greeks among those who went up to worship at the festival.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee, with a request. ‘Sir,’ they said, ‘we would like to see Jesus.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Philip went to tell Andrew; Andrew and Philip in turn told Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, unless a grain of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it remains only a single seed. But if it dies, it produces many seeds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who loves their life will lose it, while anyone who hates their life in this world will keep it for eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever serves me must follow me; and where I am, my servant also will be. My Father will honour the one who serves me.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Now my soul is troubled, and what shall I say? “Father, save me from this hour”? No, it was for this very reason I came to this hour.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Father, glorify your name!’
Then a voice came from heaven, ‘I have glorified it, and will glorify it again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd that was there and heard it said it had thundered; others said an angel had spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, ‘This voice was for your benefit, not mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now is the time for judgment on this world; now the prince of this world will be driven out.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all people to myself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said this to show the kind of death he was going to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowd spoke up, ‘We have heard from the Law that the Messiah will remain for ever, so how can you say, “The Son of Man must be lifted up”? Who is this “Son of Man”?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told them, ‘You are going to have the light just a little while longer. Walk while you have the light, before darkness overtakes you. Whoever walks in the dark does not know where they are going.
speaker: Narrator

text: Believe in the light while you have the light, so that you may become children of light.’ When he had finished speaking, Jesus left and hid himself from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even after Jesus had performed so many signs in their presence, they still would not believe in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This was to fulfil the word of Isaiah the prophet:
‘Lord, who has believed our message
    and to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?’
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason they could not believe, because, as Isaiah says elsewhere:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘He has blinded their eyes
    and hardened their hearts,
so they can neither see with their eyes,
    nor understand with their hearts,
    nor turn – and I would heal them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said this because he saw Jesus’ glory and spoke about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet at the same time many even among the leaders believed in him. But because of the Pharisees they would not openly acknowledge their faith for fear they would be put out of the synagogue;
speaker: Narrator

text: for they loved human praise more than praise from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus cried out, ‘Whoever believes in me does not believe in me only, but in the one who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who looks at me is seeing the one who sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have come into the world as a light, so that no one who believes in me should stay in darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If anyone hears my words but does not keep them, I do not judge that person. For I did not come to judge the world, but to save the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a judge for the one who rejects me and does not accept my words; the very words I have spoken will condemn them at the last day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I did not speak on my own, but the Father who sent me commanded me to say all that I have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that his command leads to eternal life. So whatever I say is just what the Father has told me to say.’
speaker: Narrator

text: It was just before the Passover Festival. Jesus knew that the hour had come for him to leave this world and go to the Father. Having loved his own who were in the world, he loved them to the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: The evening meal was in progress, and the devil had already prompted Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, to betray Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus knew that the Father had put all things under his power, and that he had come from God and was returning to God;
speaker: Narrator

text: so he got up from the meal, took off his outer clothing, and wrapped a towel round his waist.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, he poured water into a basin and began to wash his disciples’ feet, drying them with the towel that was wrapped round him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to Simon Peter, who said to him, ‘Lord, are you going to wash my feet?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, ‘You do not realise now what I am doing, but later you will understand.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘No,’ said Peter, ‘you shall never wash my feet.’
Jesus answered, ‘Unless I wash you, you have no part with me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then, Lord,’ Simon Peter replied, ‘not just my feet but my hands and my head as well!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘Those who have had a bath need only to wash their feet; their whole body is clean. And you are clean, though not every one of you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For he knew who was going to betray him, and that was why he said not every one was clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished washing their feet, he put on his clothes and returned to his place. ‘Do you understand what I have done for you?’ he asked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You call me “Teacher” and “Lord”, and rightly so, for that is what I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also should wash one another’s feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have set you an example that you should do as I have done for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, no servant is greater than his master, nor is a messenger greater than the one who sent him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that you know these things, you will be blessed if you do them.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am not referring to all of you; I know those I have chosen. But this is to fulfil this passage of Scripture: “He who shared my bread has turned against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am telling you now before it happens, so that when it does happen you will believe that I am who I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: Very truly I tell you, whoever accepts anyone I send accepts me; and whoever accepts me accepts the one who sent me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had said this, Jesus was troubled in spirit and testified, ‘Very truly I tell you, one of you is going to betray me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples stared at one another, at a loss to know which of them he meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, the disciple whom Jesus loved, was reclining next to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simon Peter motioned to this disciple and said, ‘Ask him which one he means.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Leaning back against Jesus, he asked him, ‘Lord, who is it?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, ‘It is the one to whom I will give this piece of bread when I have dipped it in the dish.’ Then, dipping the piece of bread, he gave it to Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As soon as Judas took the bread, Satan entered into him.
So Jesus told him, ‘What you are about to do, do quickly.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But no one at the meal understood why Jesus said this to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Judas had charge of the money, some thought Jesus was telling him to buy what was needed for the festival, or to give something to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Judas had taken the bread, he went out. And it was night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was gone, Jesus said, ‘Now the Son of Man is glorified and God is glorified in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If God is glorified in him, God will glorify the Son in himself, and will glorify him at once.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My children, I will be with you only a little longer. You will look for me, and just as I told the Jews, so I tell you now: where I am going, you cannot come.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘A new command I give you: love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: By this everyone will know that you are my disciples, if you love one another.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Simon Peter asked him, ‘Lord, where are you going?’
Jesus replied, ‘Where I am going, you cannot follow now, but you will follow later.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter asked, ‘Lord, why can’t I follow you now? I will lay down my life for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus answered, ‘Will you really lay down your life for me? Very truly I tell you, before the cock crows, you will disown me three times!
